Award.AwardTitle: Rapid and dynamic cell assessments in dielectrophoresis-based microfluidic devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336160
Lapizco-Encinas

Food and water safety, environmental monitoring and clinical screening are examples of fields where microfluidics can make a significant contribution, since in these areas it is critical to obtain rapid results. Working with microfluidic devices offers important advantages: small sample requirements, higher resolution and sensitivity, and shorter processing times (~minutes).

Intellectual Merit
Dielectrophoresis (DEP), an electrokinetic (EK) transport mechanism, is one of the most popular techniques used in microdevices for analyzing cells. Insulator-based DEP (iDEP) offers a dielectrophoretic mode that employs 3-dimensional insulating structures located between two external electrodes. These systems have been extensively studied employing DC potentials and high frequency AC potentials. There is, however, a significant gap in knowledge for particle behavior in iDEP systems with low frequency (< 1 kHz) AC electric potentials. The present proposal is focused on the use of low frequency AC potentials in iDEP systems.

In order to immobilize and concentrate particles in iDEP systems, DEP has to overcome electroosmotic flow (EOF). EOF is necessary as means to pump the liquid and cells through a microchannel, but it is costly for DEP to overcome EOF, since very high potentials are required, which compromises cell viability and produces heat. This proposal aims to dynamically control EOF by modifying the characteristics of an applied AC potential. This is more advantageous than eliminating EOF, since it allows controlling EOF "on the fly," leading to lower voltage requirements. There is great flexibility and novelty on the use of AC electric potentials with iDEP systems, since a new set of parameters can be used to fine tune particle and cell manipulation. By using these parameters (signal shape, frequency, amplitude, offset), EOF can be dynamically controlled to produce more effective cell manipulation at lower required potentials. This work will also employ mathematical modeling that will aid on the understanding of the fundamentals behind iDEP. Integrated systems with the application of sequences of AC and DC potentials and multipart devices comprising sections for streaming DEP and trapping DEP will also be evaluated, with the objective of achieving sorting, concentration and separation of a sample containing various cell types on a single device.

Broader Impacts
Scientific impact: The potential of iDEP has not been fully explored; there is a need for systems able to perform several processes on a single device, and low frequency AC potentials can answer this need.
This project will advance the state of the art in the applications of iDEP, addressing the gap in the low frequency regime (<1kHz). It will also advance on the knowledge of mathematical modeling of iDEP systems and fundamentals on post geometry. Schemes for cell sorting, separation and concentration will be designed, by integrating several steps of a process on a single device. The possible applications of a microscale method that can process a sample containing several types of cells in a matter of minutes are numerous. This research can make an impact in many other fields, where a rapid response of samples containing cells is critical.

Societal impact: This project will provide a premier research opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students. It will also assist in providing research opportunities for female students through the Women in Engineering program, and for minorities and underrepresented groups, including those students in the RIT Ronald E. McNair Post-Baccalaureate Achievement Program, a program dedicated to low income, first generation minority students to ensure they enter graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Food and water safety, environmental monitoring and clinical screening are examples of fields where microfluidics can make a significant contribution, since in these areas it is critical to obtain rapid results.

Working with microfluidic devices can be answer to this need for rapid analysis, microfluidic devices offers the advantage over traditional techniques of shorter processing times (~minutes), along with small sample requirements, higher resolution and sensitivity. Microfluidics has revolutionized the manner in which numerous bio-analysis are performed, therefore there is an increasing interest on the development of separation and analytical techniques that can be used in microfluidic devices.

Our work for this NSF award was focused on the development of a microfluidic technique that can be used to separate, isolate and analyze particles (including biological cells) from a given sample in manner of minutes. This technique, called Dielectrophoresis, uses electrical fields to analyze particles.  We exploit a phenomenon called particle polarization under condition where electric fields are non-uniform. We created non-uniform electric field by employing obstacles made from electrically insulating materials. We analyzed several aspects to fully characterize this technique:  particle properties (shape, size, electrical charge), obstacle properties (size, shape, arrangement within a microchannel) and also the characteristics of the applied electric field (direct current and alternating current).

 The results from this NSF award allowed us to improve particle analysis employing dielectrophoresis:

  1. We tested that this technique can be sued with very dilute samples, which is a very common challenge in bio-analysis;
  2. We proposed a new method for capturing target particles and cells by adding filler particles.
  3. We studied in detail the effect of the shape and arrangement of the insulating obstacles needed for dielectrophoresis and identified general guidelines that can be used by other scientists working with dielectrophoresis.
  4. We improved an existing technique for measuring fluid flow with electric fields, this phenomena is called electroosmosis, in particular we improved a method called “current monitoring” which is used to analyze electroosmotic flow.
  5. We proposed new ways of carrying out particle analysis with dielectrophoresis by combining direct current and alternating current electric field an also by using insulating obstacles that have asymmetrical shapes. The later, allows us to be able to very quickly analyzed cells in a  sample, which can be very useful, as cells are very fragile and therefore should be exposed to electrical field for a short period of time.

The results obtained from this project advanced the field of microfluidics and dielectrophoretic separations. All of these research results were published in 10 peer-reviewed journal articles and in 37 conference presentations. Also, the students working on this project obtained eight student awards at international conferences.  A total of seven students worked on this project, five were undergraduate and two were graduate students.  Four students were female and three students were minority. All undergraduate students involved are now published authors of journal articles, this gives them an advantage when applying to graduate school, since they already have a publication record that includes both, journal articles and conference presentations.  Two of the undergraduate students have five or more journal articles in their publication record, which is very rare.

Furthermore, this NSF award also enabled two distinct outreach activities:

  1. Women in Engineering workshop:  We ran FOUR times (08/2014, 08/2015, 08/2016 and 08/2017) the laboratory experience “Moving liquid and particles with electricity” as part of a Women in Engineering event “We’re in motion.”  The goal was to introduce these young women to engineering by showing them that there are many fields and branches of engineering. We showed them a novel area of engineering: microfluidics; which is a multi-disciplinary area.
  2. Middle School workshop: In March 2015 and April 2017 we conducted a Workshop on Microfluidics & Diffusion to middle school students (6th grade) from Rochester school 43.  In this workshop the students made small channels from Jell-O using cast-molding techniques, very similar to what we use in our laboratory to make devices from polydimethylsiloxane.  After the channels were ready, we introduced two different dyes and the students observed the mixing of the two dyes through diffusion. They learned fundamental concepts of microfluidics, such as laminar flow, and mass transfer with Fick’s law of diffusion. The workshop was followed by a comprehension exercise given by their Teacher Brian Lynch (http://www.rcsdk12.org/Page/10058) that demonstrated that the students grasped successfully these complex concepts.   Workshop information is published here: https://www.rit.edu/kgcoe/biomedical/story/microscale-bioseparations-lab-hosted-outreach-workshop-microfluidics-diffusion.
